newsitem.title: ZIMBABWE: ZIMBABWE MONEY RATES STEADY TO HIGHER.
newsitem.headline: ZIMBABWE MONEY RATES STEADY TO HIGHER.

text.p: Short-term trading rates on Zimbabwe's money market were steady to higher in dull Tuesday trade, dealers said.
"The market is a bit quiet at the moment, nothing much is happening," said one dealer.

He said discount houses were indicating to sell treasury bills at 17.75 percent, a notch up from 17.70 percent the previous day, and call money was also quoted firmer at 18.50 percent compared to Monday's 18.25 percent.

Bankers acceptance bills were being bought at a steady 18.50 percent but sold at 17.75 up from 17.70 percent while NCD bills redeemable after 30, 60 and 90 days were unchanged at 19.50 percent (buying) and at 18.25 percent (selling).
Central Reserve Bank figures indicated a surplus of Z$356 million under Monday's date, up from Z$28 million previously. --Stella Mapenzauswa, Harare Newsroom: +263-4 72 52 28/9--
